newsitem.title: FRANCE: France's Socialists won't raise taxes - Aubry.
newsitem.headline: France's Socialists won't raise taxes - Aubry.

text.p: France's opposition Socialist party will not hike taxes if it wins a snap parliamentary election but will merely change their distribution, former labour minister Martine Aubry said on Thursday.
"We will not raise taxes," Aubry, a member of the party's leadership, said in an interview with RTL radio amid campaigning for the May 25-June 1 vote.
"We will simply make a better share-out between income from capital and income from salaries, we will relaunch consumption and we will introduce a new development model," she said.

She accused the centre-right government of Prime Minister Alain Juppe of preparing new austerity to ensure France meets the budget criteria for a single European currency -- a deficit of less than three percent of gross domestic product.
The government has said that France is on target to meet the Maastricht criteria with its present policies and is not planning any new austerity.
Aubry, daughter of former European Commission president Jacques Delors, said the three percent target "is not the Bible...the treaty itself says that the trend must be taken into account."
"If today we don't respect the Maastricht criteria, it's because there is not enough growth, because salaries have been hit, because consumption is falling," she said.
The Socialists say they favour the single currency, but not at the price of a new bout of austerity.
Former Socialist party boss Henri Emmanuelli said France would not meet the Maastricht criteria on current economic performance. "That means a new swing to austerity," he told France Inter radio.

Emmanuelli denied that Socialist conditions for a single currency, including the participation from the start of Italy and Spain, were a way of wooing voters of the Communist party, which opposes the single currency.
"I don't have the impression that France fears the Communist party gripping power or the economy in France," he said. "Let's be serious. Those are arguments people brought out in the 1970s."
